diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition more common in children that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's characterized by fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, irritation and redness in the whites of the eyes (conjunctivitis), swollen lymph nodes in the neck (cervical lymphadenopathy), and oral mucous membrane changes.

diagnoses.name: Adult-onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash, and joint pain. Some patients may show signs of conjunctivitis and occasional lymphadenopathy. Increased levels of certain white blood cells (leukocytosis) and elevated platelet counts (thrombocytosis) can be laboratory indicators for this disease.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called 'mono' or the 'kissing disease,' this condition is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Symptoms include fatigue, fever, inflamed throat, swollen lymph nodes in the neck, enlarged spleen, swollen liver, and sometimes a reddish rash.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by periods of illness, called flares, and periods of wellness, or remission. Symptoms include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever. It might also cause lymphadenopathy and rarely, conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Leukemias
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. Various types exist such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), acute myeloid leukemia (AML), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), and chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Symptoms can include fever, frequent infections, tiredness, easy bleeding or bruising, and swollen lymph nodes. In some cases, thrombocytosis can be observed.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of poorly treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms include fever, painful and tender joints, rash and nodules under the skin, and unusual body movements, commonly in children.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps, known as granulomas, in various organs. The primary symptoms include tiredness, swollen lymph nodes, weight loss, pain and swelling in the bones, and a rash on the skin.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, which is part of the immune system. Symptoms include painless swelling of lymph nodes in your neck, armpits, or groin, persistent fatigue, fever, night sweats, and unexplained weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma which includes all types of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms are similar to Hodgkin Lymphoma, including swollen lymph nodes, fever, belly pain, chest pain, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in various parts of the body but is often concentrated in the joints, urinary tract, and eyes. It usually develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity). Symptoms can include conjunctivitis, urethritis, arthritis, and cervicitis in women.

diagnoses: Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (Coxsackievirus Infection)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Parvovirus B19 infection (Erythema infectiosum or Fifth disease)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., Systemic lupus erythematosus)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including autoimmune hemolysis, skin manifestations like annular rashes, and serositis leading to acute pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting joints, rheumatoid arthritis can have systemic manifestations including pleural effusions and, more rarely, pericarditis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.reason: MCTD features symptoms of various autoimmune diseases including lupus. It can present with symptoms such as autoimmune hemolysis, pericarditis, and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: While known mostly for affecting the salivary and lacrimal glands, Sjögren's can have systemic effects, including pleural effusions and, rarely, hematological manifestations such as autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: This condition can present with characteristic rashes, including annular rashes, and systemic features may include pericarditis. There is also an association with pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: Sarcoidosis can lead to granulomatous inflammation affecting various organs. It can cause acute pericarditis and pleural effusions; skin manifestations can sometimes mimic annular rashes.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Hematological cancers such as lymphoma can cause autoimmune hemolysis, pleural and pericardial effusions, and nonspecific skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia. It can indirectly lead to other systemic symptoms but is less likely to cause the skin and serous membrane symptoms directly.

diagnoses.name: Infectious causes
diagnoses.reason: Certain infections can mimic autoimmune diseases by causing a widespread inflammatory response leading to symptoms such as pericarditis, effusions, and skin rashes. Examples include viral infections like Parvovirus B19 and bacterial infections such as streptococcal species.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome, presenting with symptoms similar to SLE including pericarditis, pleural effusion, and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, skin, blood, and heart, causing inflammation and tissue damage in the organs involved.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic inflammation, potentially affecting the pericardium and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.description: Various viruses can lead to conditions such as pericarditis and leukopenia. For example, Coxsackievirus is known to cause myocarditis and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome that occurs after the exposure to certain prescription drugs, which can induce symptoms like pericarditis and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder with overlapping features of several connective tissue diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, and can involve multiple organ systems.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease of connective tissue marked by skin thickening and hardening, an abnormal growth of connective tissue, which can also affect internal organs including the kidneys and heart.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can lead to complications including fluid retention, electrolyte imbalances, and effects on other organs such as the heart.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system. If not treated, it can lead to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS), which deteriorates the immune system and allows life-threatening infections and cancers to thrive.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body, including the pericardium and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.description: A condition involving abnormally high levels of waste products in the blood, typically due to underlying kidney disease. This syndrome can affect multiple systems including the cardiovascular system, potentially leading to pericarditis.

diagnoses.reasoning: Presents with fever, maculopapular rash, and leukopenia. Psychosis is rare but can occur in severe cases.
Symptoms include fever, rash, and leukopenia. Neurological manifestations such as psychosis can occur, though they are less common.
Known for causing fever, rash, and can lead to Guillain-Barre syndrome, which might present with psychiatric symptoms. Leukopenia is also possible.
Diseases such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever can cause fever, rash, and leukopenia. Neuropsychiatric symptoms can also manifest.
An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms including fever, rash (including a malar rash), leukopenia, and neuropsychiatric symptoms such as psychosis.
Characterized by rash, fever, and possible leukopenia. Neuropsychiatric symptoms can occur in the form of syphilitic meningitis or, later, neurosyphilis.
Presents with fever, maculopapular rash, and can cause leukopenia. Neurological complications, including psychotic episodes, can occur, though rare.
Early infection can present with fever, rash, and leukopenia. Neurological complications, including neuropsychiatric symptoms, can occur at any stage.
Can cause a wide range of symptoms including fever, rash, and leukopenia. Severe cases can affect the kidneys and liver, potentially leading to neurological symptoms.
Caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and presents with fever, rash, and leukopenia. Neurological manifestations, including altered mental status, can occur.

diagnoses: Viral Infection (e.g., Coxsackie B, Echo, HIV)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as discoid rash (skin lesions that are red, inflamed, and often scaly), pleural effusion (excess fluid around the lungs), synovitis (inflammation of the synovial membrane in joints), dyspigmentation (changes in skin color), and proteinuria (protein in the urine), indicating potential kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing joint pain and synovitis, RA can lead to extra-articular manifestations including rheumatoid nodules and potential lung involvement (pleural effusion), but discoid rash and proteinuria are less common.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory condition characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash including dyspigmentation. Although it primarily affects the skin and muscles, it can lead to systemic issues, including lung problems (potential for pleural effusion) and, less commonly, kidney issues manifesting as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This rare autoimmune disorder can manifest with features of several other conditions, including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Symptoms can include Raynaud's phenomenon, synovitis, lung involvement with pleural effusion, skin rashes such as discoid rash, and renal involvement that may lead to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disease affecting the skin, causing dyspigmentation and tightness, and can affect internal organs. It may lead to interstitial lung disease and pleural effusion but is less commonly associated with synovitis and proteinuria than SLE.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting salivary and lacrimal glands leading to dry eyes and mouth, Sjögren's can have systemic manifestations including joint pain or synovitis, and lung involvement such as pleural effusion; however, discoid rash and proteinuria are less typical.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis can cause synovitis and skin manifestations, including rashes distinct from the discoid rashes of lupus. It can occasionally affect the kidneys, causing proteinuria, and lung involvement, including pleural effusion, is rare.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: A systemic vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries that can cause skin symptoms (such as rash and dyspigmentation), kidney involvement (proteinuria), and occasionally musculoskeletal symptoms like synovitis, but pleural effusion is not a common manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: A specific manifestation of SLE affecting the kidneys, leading to proteinuria and potentially systemic symptoms as seen in SLE, including discoid rash and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder often associated with SLE, characterized by blood clots and complications in pregnancy. While primarily known for vascular symptoms, it can be associated with a range of manifestations that can mimic or occur alongside SLE, including skin lesions (though not typically discoid rash), potential kidney involvement (proteinuria), and pleural effusion in severe cases.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Ebola Virus)

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.rationale: ADHD can account for attention deficit symptoms and potentially exacerbate stress, possibly influencing the development of ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Major Neurocognitive Disorder
diagnoses.rationale: May explain attention deficit, word-finding difficulty, and dysosmia due to generalized cognitive decline.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Directly accounts for the presentation of ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Dyslipidemia
diagnoses.rationale: Identified as a separate condition that might be influenced by stress and dietary habits linked to other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress or Anxiety
diagnoses.rationale: Can indirectly cause or exacerbate symptoms like attention deficit, ulcers, and potentially dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Mild Cognitive Impairment
diagnoses.rationale: May lead to symptoms such as word-finding difficulty and attention deficit, especially in early stages.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Lobe Epilepsy
diagnoses.rationale: Could explain word-finding difficulty, attention deficits, and dysosmia due to focal seizures affecting the temporal lobe.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.rationale: Can manifest with cognitive symptoms such as impaired attention, memory issues, and physical symptoms like ulcers due to stress and poor self-care.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.rationale: Could explain dysosmia (reduced sense of smell) and possibly contribute to attention deficit and cognitive difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.rationale: May cause cognitive problems including attention deficit and word-finding difficulty, as well as contribute to peptic ulcer development.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic esophagitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic condition causing inflammation of the esophagus often associated with food hypersensitivity and can manifest with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach, causing irritation and potentially exacerbating hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can cause some of the vertebrae in your spine to fuse together, leading to chronic pain and stiffness in the back and sometimes linked with gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that can affect skin and mucous membranes, sometimes responsible for lesions in the mouth like leukoplakia and potentially linked with hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, which can cause chronic gastrointestinal symptoms including those similar to gastroesophageal reflux and can be associated with leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis that can cause significant joint pain, stiffness, and can also have gastrointestinal manifestations in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Pain Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex condition involving a variety of chronic pain experiences, including back pain, without a definitive cause and possibly related to hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
diagnoses.description: A form of skin cancer that can occur in the mouth and lead to leukoplakia. Chronic inflammation or irritation, such as from GERD, might increase the risk.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues, which may be linked to pain processing pathways related to hypersensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: Ulcers are sores on the lining of your stomach or small intestine often caused by the H. pylori bacteria or long-term use of NSAIDs. Symptoms can overlap with GERD, such as heartburn and pain.

diagnoses: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis (in cases of fluctuating thyroid function)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and scotoma (vision loss or blind spot).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like muscle weakness, visual disturbances including scotoma, and sometimes nausea.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: An abscess caused by an infection in the brain, which can lead to symptoms including headache, nausea, weakness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, nausea, weakness, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain, leading to sudden headache, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and sometimes focal neurological deficits such as weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include weakness on one side of the body, difficulty speaking, headache, and possibly visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve, which can cause vision loss or disturbance such as scotoma, pain with eye movement, and in some cases, nausea and general weakness.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain tissue, often caused by viral infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, weakness, and in severe cases, seizures and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Glaucoma
diagnoses.description: A group of eye conditions that can cause damage to the optic nerve, leading to vision loss and possibly scotoma. Advanced stages can lead to eye pain and headache, possibly affecting light sensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Pituitary Tumor
diagnoses.description: Non-cancerous growths in the pituitary gland which can affect hormonal balance and lead to various symptoms, including headaches, nausea, vision problems like scotoma, and in some cases, muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden dysphagia, headache, dysarthria, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can press on nerve cells in the brain, causing symptoms such as headache, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), speech problems (dysarthria), and language difficulties (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis is a disease where the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause dysphagia, headache, dysarthria, and aphasia due to lesions in the central nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease, affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. It can cause symptoms including difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), speech problems (dysarthria), but aphasia and headache are less common.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: Myasthenia Gravis is a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by fluctuating weakness of the voluntary muscle groups, and can cause dysphagia and dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or injury. Symptoms can include headache, dysphagia, dysarthria, and sometimes aphasia, depending on the abscess location.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. While dysphagia and dysarthria can occur, aphasia and headache are less common.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Brainstem Aura
diagnoses.description: This type of migraine previously known as basilar-type migraine can cause dysarthria, vertigo, tinnitus, decreased hearing, double vision, ataxia, decreased level of consciousness, and sometimes dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina. It can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, such as dysarthria, aphasia but usually resolves within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: Primary Progressive Aphasia is a form of cognitive impairment that involves a progressive loss of language function. Dysarthria and aphasia are prominent features, while dysphagia can occur as the disease progresses.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech, and weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense pain, sensitivity to light and sound, and nausea. Migraine with aura includes visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms that appear about 20 to 60 minutes before the headache starts.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief episode of neurological dysfunction caused by an interruption in the blood supply to the brain or eye, without acute infarction. Symptoms mirror those of a stroke but typically last less than an hour and do not result in permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can disrupt brain function by pushing on certain parts of the brain, leading to symptoms such as weakness, hearing loss, nausea, and difficulties with speech. The symptoms can vary significantly depending on the tumor’s location.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune, inflammatory neurological disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. It may cause vision problems, tiredness, impaired coordination, weakness, and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: Meniere's Disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, only one ear is affected. Symptoms can vary from mild to severe and may include a ringing sensation in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, or pressure in the affected ear.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: An acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor that develops on the nerve that connects the ear to the brain. The tumor usually grows slowly and can cause hearing loss, ringing in your ear, and loss of balance.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: Temporal arteritis is an inflammation of the blood vessels, usually in the temples, that can cause a headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision problems, and even irreversible blindness. Symptoms may include sudden onset of headache, vision disturbances, and can affect speech.

diagnoses.name: Labyrinthitis
diagnoses.description: Labyrinthitis is an inner ear infection that causes a structure deep inside your ear (the labyrinth) to become inflamed. Symptoms can include dizziness, loss of balance, nausea, hearing loss in one ear, and difficulties with concentration.

diagnoses.name: Vascular Dementia
diagnoses.description: Vascular dementia is the second most common form of dementia after Alzheimer's disease. It occurs when the vessels that supply blood to the brain become blocked or narrowed, leading to symptoms such as confusion, disorientation, trouble speaking or understanding speech, and weakness.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Iron deficiency anemia due to chronic blood loss
